body.p:
Accept my thanks for inserting, in the occident
of this month, my first letter on the union &c. It is thought much
of here, perhaps more than it deserves. I am not over greedy of praise
but if my labours contribute, in the smallest degree, to promote the good
cause, it will I confess make me happy, and amply compensate me.

I have now the pleasure of handing you Letter 3, on
subjects confessedly difficult to be properly treated. Whether I have succee=
=ded or not in my expositions, and to what degree will be judged by the public
before whom my letters are to be placed.

I read very attentively your excellent article on “The
Results of Union.” it came very opportunely, and I availed myself
of it, as you will perceive in my 3 Letter, to induce patient attention to
my exposition. Your remarks and suggestions, and my two first letters
ought to suffice for the purposes of the suggested meeting. Our Folks
scarcely ever proceed at Railway speed, therefore what you may further
suggest and I may publish will be in very good time and keeping, even
if issued after holding the meeting, for the Union should it ever take
place. I shall therefore continue my exposition, and though not as fully
as might be done, I will still endeavour to render it as useful and interesting
as I can, by neglecting nothing that I think might conduce to those ends.

I expect the pleasure of a letter from you in acknow=
ledgment of that I wrote you on forwarding to you my 2nd Letter on the Union.
I am anxious to learn if you approve of and intend, on my suggestion, announcing
at once in the occident for march, the meeting for Rosh Hodesh Sivan, the
22nd May, at New York. In your article “The results of Union” page

page 539, I observe something like a too much waiting upon others?
announce the meeting and I will venture to insure an attendance of
at least a dozen—quite enough, and perhaps better than a greater number
to resolve on constituting itself the suggested society, which many will
subsequently join. Forgoing that far neither much labour nor money
will be required, whilst it may be the means of eventual success in
the object we have in view. If the meeting take place at New York many
of the laymen of that city will doubtless attend. I have in view as many
as a dozen including laymen and ministers that would be present at the
meeting. Dr. WiseEach name is labeled with a number above it—1, 2, 3, 4, etc., Dr. Lilienthall, Revd. Mr. Isaacs, Revd Mr. Lyons,
Revd Mr Leo, Revd Isaac Leeser, Mr Abm Kursheedt, His Father,
Mr. Abm Hart N/Y. Mr. Noah, Dr. J. I. Cohen, Balt. Revd Mr Gutheime
Revd Mr Hart, Phil. Myself. There number 14 and surely many more of
the Gentlemen from Albany, New York, Philadelphia, and Baltimore,
to say nothing of Cincinnati, & other portions of the Union who may chance
to be at New York at the time, it may be reasonably expected will attend.

My son visited Dr. Rice at Baltimore. The reverend
Gentleman persisted in saying he would not attend the meeting, giving
for reason that he thought a meeting of ministers could have no result,
and that one of talented laymen would be likely to have more: He added
that he might, however, yet determine on attending. I hope he may but if
he do not we must strive to do as well as we can without him.

Have you considered my request to have 50 copies of each
of my letters struck off before breaking the forms in order to their being made up
as a pamphlet. I hope you will have the goodness to gratify me in this
I am ever revd sir Yours faithfully A A Lindo
